ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really developed my french skills.
A greater knowledge of French grammar. You build on the past tenses, learn future and conditional tenses, and you begin to learn the subjunctive. Writing, pronunciation, and speaking improve a bit.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Sometimes was hard to engage over zoom but otherwise a nice class.
It should be adjusted to the work level of students.

Strengths: You definitely will learn more French than you think. The biweekly tests were better than 110's weekly tests because it was less stressful. The course packet has some really nice practice problems (though I wish we had the answer key with it) 

Weaknesses: I think guided reading would have been really helpful. Sometimes we read by ourselves in pairs via breakout rooms, but I think having the professor read the passage so we could follow along would've been more helpful because I didn't know how to pronounce a lot of words and didn't learn how to through individual reading. More feedback in general in terms of pronunciation and speaking would have been great.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout rooms were very helpful in terms of keeping the class engaging. PowerPoints with the answer keys were very nice in terms of review.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes to anyone who seriously wants to learn French.

If you want to learn French then this course will definitely do that for you. I would be careful with the workload though. It includes one to two 30 minute videos per week along with the corresponding workbook exercises (which can get pretty long) as well as biweekly tests, quizzes, and composition writings.

I feel like the French department is very good. It's a lot of work, but it helps if you want to learn French quickly. I mainly hate the workbook because the questions and problems you do for homework don't really help with the content that shows up on exams and quizzes. It helps a bit, but mainly feels like busy work.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
